label: Aaron
description: See Montezuma.

label: Abbotts Creek
description: community in NE Davidson County. A Primitive Baptist church was founded there in 1756. Gen. Nathanael Greene camped there in February 1781 before the Battle of Guilford Courthouse.

label: Abbotts Creek Township
description: NE Davidson County.

label: Adams Branch
description: rises in S central Transylvania County and flows S into French Broad River.

label: Adams Creek
description: rises in central Cabarrus County and flows SE into Dutch Buffalo Creek. Named for John Adam Blackwelder, an early settler.

label: Adams Creek
description: rises in central Carteret County and flows N into Craven County, where it enters Neuse River. A canal connecting the headwaters of Adams Creek with Newport River provides access between Newport and Neuse Rivers for the Intracoastal Waterway. For a part of its course, Adams Creek forms the boundary between Carteret and Craven Counties.

label: Adams Store
description: community in N Halifax County.

label: Airlie
description: community in W Halifax County. Named for plantation home of jurist Walter Clark (1846-1924).

label: Albright Township
description: former township in S central Alamance County, now township no. 7.

label: All Healing Springs
description: community in W Alexander County. Springs discovered in 1882 by Milt Milstead and developed as a resort that was popular as late as 1911. Named for supposed healing qualities of water; known also as Alkalithia Springs. Alt. 1,225.

label: All Healing Springs
description: community in SW Gaston County near the NE slope of Crowders Mountain. A health resort flourished there in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries because of the mineral springs.

label: Allan Creek
description: rises in S Duplin County and flows S into Island Creek.

label: Allen Branch
description: rises in N Cherokee County and flows SE into Davis Creek.

label: Allen Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows S into Junaluska Creek.

label: Allen Branch
description: rises in central Henderson County and flows NW into Clear Creek.

label: Allen Branch
description: See Bill Allen Branch.

label: Allen Creek
description: rises in SE Brunswick County and flows NE into McKenzie Pond, which see. It is drained by Lilliput Creek. Named for Eleazer Allen (1692-1750), founder of Lilliput Plantation. Name appears on the MacRae map, 1833. See also Lilliput Creek.

label: Allen Mountain
description: in S Macon County between Ball Creek and Coweeta Creek.

label: Allen's Crossroads
description: community in SW Johnston County.

label: Allens Branch
description: rises in E Orange County and flows NE into New Hope Creek.

label: Allenton
description: community in E Robeson County. Alt. 131. Settled about 1868. Named for W. H. Allen, trainmaster. Bear Bay, post office 1 mi. e, abandoned with the development of Allenton.

label: Alligator Bay
description: swamp in NW Brunswick County. A part of Green Swamp, which see.

label: Alligator Creek
description: rises in E central Camden County and flows E into North River.

label: Alligator Creek
description: rises in central Pamlico County and flows N into Bay River.

label: Alligator Creek
description: rises in N Tyrrell County and flows SE and NE into the mouth of Alligator River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Allison Creek
description: rises in S central Transylvania County, just S of Elk Lodge Mountain, and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Alum Knob

label: Amherst

label: Ammons Branch

label: Ammons Branch
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows SW into Cullasaja River.

label: Ammons Branch

label: Ammons Branch

label: Arabia

label: Archdale
description: town in NW Randolph County. Settled about 1786 by Quakers. Inc. 1874 as Bush Hill; named for the fact that the area was originally covered with a growth of low bushes. Name changed to Archdale, 1887, in honor of John Archdale (1642?-1717), a Quaker, one of the Lords Proprietors of Carolina, and governor, 1694-96. Original post office was ½ mi. from present site and named Bloomington until moved to Bush Hill in 1865. Archdale is now a residential suburb of High Point.

label: Arlington
description: community in W Harnett County between the Cape Fear River and Upper Little River.

label: Arlington
description: town in NE Mecklenburg County on Clear Creek. Inc. 1930, but long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Arlington

label: Asbury

label: Ashland

label: Atlantic Township

label: Back Creek

Appears as Barbacue Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Big Bald
description: on the Yancey County, N.C.-Unicoi County, Tenn., line. Peak in Yancey County is at the N end of Hensley Ridge. Alt. 5,516. Known by the Indians as Sasseenohla (white man). Previously called Grier Bald for David Grier, spurned lover of the daughter of Col. David Vance. He lived there from 1802 until 1834, when he was killed for having killed a hunter who "trespassed" on the mountain. Much of the mountain is covered by mounds, ranging from the size of a football to a bushel basket, that emit a hollow sound when struck. Scientists theorize that the mounds are the rotted roots of balsam and spruce trees blown over by a storm centuries ago. See also The Arm.

label: Blue Ridge Parkway
description: an elongated park with a scenic motorway following the crest of the Blue Ridge Mountains from Shenandoah National Park in Virginia to the Great Smoky Mountains National Park in North Carolina and Tennessee. It averages more than 3,000 ft. above sea level. There are a number of wayside parks, marked historic sites (including cabins and farm buildings), a mineral museum, scenic overlooks, and other points of interest along the way. Construction began on September 11, 1935, and was completed in 1987 with the opening of the Linn Cove Viaduct, which see, around Grandfather Mountain. Extends 469 mi. The parkway enters North Carolina in NE Alleghany County and extends SW for 252.1 mi.

label: Craven County
description: was formed in 1705 as Archdale Precinct of Bath County, although there is evidence that an Archdale County, which see, existed as early as 1696. The name was changed to Craven County about 1712. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by Carteret, Jones, Lenoir, Pitt, Beaufort, and Pamlico Counties. It has been said that the county was named for William, Earl of Craven (1606-97), one of the original Lords Proprietors and longest lived of the eight. More likely, however, it was named for his grandnephew, William, Lord Craven (who inherited his title and interest in Carolina and who died the year before the name of the county was changed from Archdale to Craven); or for the third William, Lord Craven, one of the Proprietors at the time the change in the name of the county was made. Area: 785 sq. mi. County seat: New Bern, with an elevation of 12 ft. Townships are nos. 1-3, 5-9; all of former township no. 4 was included in Pamlico County when it was created in 1872. Produces tobacco, corn, soybeans, peanuts, hogs, dairy products, processed meat, lumber, boats, and apparel.

description: N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending SE from Mount Collins.

label: Fork Ridge
description: N Swain County, extends SW from Thomas Ridge between Left Fork and Right Fork to the confluence of the forks to form Indian Creek.

label: Fork Ridge
description: N Yancey County parallel to Hensley Branch.

label: Fork Swamp
description: rises in SW Beaufort County in Reedy Pocosin and flows S into Craven County, where it enters Palmetta Swamp. Named because an adjacent road forks, one road leading to Pinetown and the other route to Washington, N.C.

label: Fork Township
description: SE Warren County.

label: Forked Ridge
description: NE Buncombe County SW of Slaty Branch.

label: Forked Ridge
description: on the Henderson-Transylvania county line.

label: Fort Branch
description: rises in NW Bertie County and flows N into Hertford County where it enters Ahoskie Creek.

label: Fort Branch
description: a Confederate fort at Rainbow Banks, NW Martin County. Built to prevent Union gunboats from going up the Roanoke River to Weldon to attack the railroad bridge. Earthworks remain.

label: Fort Dobbs
description: built 1755-56 to protect W counties from Indians. Site in N central Iredell County, 4½ mi. N of Statesville.

label: Fountain
description: community in SE Duplin County.

label: Fountain Hill
description: community in W Anson and E Union Counties.

label: Fourmile Branch
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows NW into French Broad River ½ mi. S of The Lagoon.

label: Fox Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows NW into Ivy River.

label: Fox Creek
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows SW into Tar River.

label: Fox Creek
description: rises in W Granville County and flows S into Shelton Creek.

label: Franklin
description: town and county seat in central Macon County on Little Tennessee River. Alt. 2,113. Settled prior to 1828; inc. 1855. Named for Jesse Franklin (1760-1823), governor of North Carolina, 1820-21. A mound there marks the site of the old Cherokee town Nikwasi. A council of Sir Alexander Cuming with the Indians there led to a treaty in 1730. Produces textiles and lumber.

label: Franklin Township
description: central Macon County.

label: Franklin Township
description: NE Rowan County.

label: Franklinville
description: town in E Randolph County on Deep River. Inc. 1847 as Franklinsville. Named in honor of Jesse Franklin (1760-1832), governor of North Carolina, 1820-21. Site acquired in 1801 by Christian Morris, who built a gristmill there; purchased in 1820 by Elisha Coffin, who, with others, built a cotton mill there in 1838.

label: Frederick
description: community in SW Beaufort County. Settled 1908 and named for Frederick H. von Eberstein, local farmer.

label: Frenchs Creek
description: rises in SE Bladen County and flows S into Cape Fear River.

label: Friar Swamp
description: rises in SE Bladen County and flows S into Columbus County, where it enters Buckhead Swamp. Council Mill Pond is on Friar Swamp.

label: Friendship
description: community in W Guilford County, est. 1833. Alt. 893. Named for a Friends (Quaker) meetinghouse.

label: Friendship
description: community in SW Wake County. Settled about 1800 and named for a church previously est. there. Also known as Jordans. Alt. 350.

label: Frog Level
description: community in W central Pitt County. Alt. 81.

label: Frog Level
description: See Clingman.

label: Frozen Knob
description: on the Madison County, N.C.-Unicoi County, Tenn., line.

label: Fruitland
description: community in N Henderson County on Kyles Creek. Named for large quantity of apples traditionally produced in the vicinity. Site of Fruitland Baptist Institute, training ground for Baptist ministers.

label: Galloway Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Gap Creek
description: community in S Ashe County. Formerly copper was mined in the vicinity.

label: Gap Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows SE into Cane Creek.

label: Garden City
description: community in central New Hanover County. Alt. 15. Settled about 1912. Named for natural beauty of area.

label: Garden Creek
description: rises in E Haywood County and flows NE into Pigeon River. One of the earliest settlements in the county was at a wide bottom on the stream, which still is known by its earliest name, Garden Farm.

label: Garren Mountain
description: SE Buncombe County SW of Dyeleaf Mountain.

label: Gaston
description: former town in NW Northampton County on Roanoke River. It developed as the N terminus of the Raleigh and Gaston Railroad, chartered 1835 and completed 1840. The town began to decline after 1865 when the bridge across the Roanoke River was burned. Named for Judge William Gaston (1778-1844). The site is now under the waters of Roanoke Rapids Lake. The modern community of Thelma, across the river, is S of the site. See also South Gaston.

label: George Branch
description: rises on the Buncombe-Haywood county line near Grassy Top and flows SE into Hominy Creek.

label: Georgetown
description: community in S Jackson County served by post office, 1854-1907.

label: Gibbs Point
description: peninsula extending into the mouth of North Landing River, NE Currituck County. A nearby community is known as Gibbs Woods. Site of the home of Capt. John Gibbs, who in 1690 claimed to be governor of Albemarle. The Moseley map, 1733, shows the area as "Gover. Gibbs's Point."

label: Gibbs Point
description: point of land extending into Pamlico Sound from S Hatteras Island N of the community of Avon, S Dare County. Probably named for Henry Gibbs, who had a grant of land on Hatteras Island in 1716.

label: Gibby Branch
description: rises in W Macon County and flows E into Choga Creek.

label: Gibson Cove
description: in NW Jackson County between Gibson Knob and Tuckasegee River.

label: Gibson Knob
description: NW Jackson County between Gibson Cove and Peggy Gap.

label: Gibson Ridge
description: central Macon County between Wallace Branch and Gibson Cove Branch.

label: Giles Creek
description: rises in N Franklin County and flows SW into Tooles Creek.

label: Glade Creek
description: rises in central Alexander County and flows S into Lower Little River to form Bell River, which see.

label: Glade Creek
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows SE into Broad River.

label: Glade Creek
description: rises in SE Macon County and flows NE into Chatooga River.

label: Glade Creek
description: rises in NE Transylvania County and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Glade Mountain
description: NW Buncombe County E of Cherry Gap.

label: Glade Mountain
description: E Haywood County between head of Thickety Creek and head of Willow Creek. Peaks are Goat Rock, Wines Top, and Point Lookout.

label: Glade, The
description: a relatively level area on Newfound Mountain on the Buncombe-Haywood county line between Grassy Gap and Beaverdam Gap.

label: Glady Fork
description: rises on the Buncombe-Henderson county line N of Glady Fork Gap and flows NW into South Hominy Creek.

label: Glenn
description: community in NW Ashe County. Alt. approx. 3,500.

label: Glenwood
description: former community in central Guilford County now within Greensboro city limits.

label: Glenwood
description: community in S Johnston County served by post office, 1884-1904.

label: Gloucester
description: town authorized to be laid off in 1754 on 50 acres of land owned by John Jenkins on the S side of the Pee Dee River in Anson County. No evidence exists that the town was ever est.

label: Goat Island
description: S central Carteret County in Bogue Sound off Morehead City.

label: Goat Knob
description: S Jackson County S of Coldside Mountain near Chester Branch.

label: Goins Creek
description: community in NW Rockingham County settled by Melungeons in early nineteenth century. Served by local "Indian School," 1943-55.

label: Gold Hill
description: community in SW Rockingham County. Name said to be derived from "discovery" of gold, which turned out to be only mica.

label: Gold Hill
description: town in S Rowan County. Gold was discovered there in 1824, and the community soon developed. Inc. 1859; reincorporated 1874, but long inactive in municipal affairs. Extensive mining operations carried on there over a long period of years. Alt. 764.

label: Gold Mine Branch
description: rises in N Graham County and flows E into Cheoah River.

label: Goldmine Branch
description: rises in W Swain County and flows S into Tuckasegee River.

label: Goldmine Branch
description: rises near Forge Mountain on the Henderson-Transylvania county line and flows NE into Boylston Creek.

label: Goodman Branch
description: rises in E central Brunswick County and flows S into Town Creek.

label: Goodman Swamp
description: rises in NW Bladen County and flows SW into Robeson County, where it enters Big Swamp.

label: Goose Creek
description: forming a part of the boundary between Beaufort and Pamlico Counties, is formed on the county line by the junction of Campbell and Upper Spring Creeks. It flows N into Pamlico River. The Intracoastal Waterway connects Goose Creek and Jones Bay.

label: Goose Creek
description: formerly rose in S Clay County and flowed NW into Hiwassee River. Its course is now covered by the waters of Chatuge Lake.

label: Goose Creek
description: rises in E Gates County and flows SE and E into Dismal Swamp.

label: Goose Creek
description: rises in SE Hertford County and flows SE into Chowan River.

label: Goose Creek
description: rises in E Mecklenburg County and flows SE into Union County, where it turns NE to enter Rocky River.

label: Goose Creek
description: rises in E Onslow County and flows SE into Sanders Creek. Mentioned in local records as early as 1744.

label: Goose Creek
description: rises in W Pamlico County and flows SW into Neuse River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Goose Creek
description: rises in E Swain County and flows SE into Oconaluftee River.

label: Goshen
description: community in W Granville County. The home of Gen. Thomas Person (1733-1800), known by biblical name of Goshen, was there. Homestead burned in 1930s. Goshen District in 1790 had 67 heads of families.

label: Goshen
description: community in NE Sampson County at the head of Goshen Swamp.

label: Gouges Creek
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows SE into North Toe River.

label: Governors Island
description: community in E Swain County on Johnson Branch. Takes its name from an adjoining loamy area on the Tuckasegee River.

label: Graham Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County and flows SE into Slow Creek.

label: Granite Falls
description: a 35-ft. waterfall in Gunpowder Creek, SE Caldwell County. Known first as Falls of Gunpowder. Baird's Forge or Baird Iron Works est. there, 1795, by Maj. Andrew Baird.

label: Grants
description: community in central Wayne County.

label: Grants Creek
description: rises in NE Onslow County and flows NE into White Oak River. Named for Alexander Grant, an early settler. A 1730 reference to the stream in local records calls it Alex's Creek. Known by present name since 1744.

label: Grape Branch
description: rises in NE Duplin County and flows SW into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Grape Branch
description: rises in S Jones County and flows SE into White Oak River.

label: Grape Creek
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SE and SW into Hiwassee River.

label: Grape Creek
description: rises in Great Dover Swamp, N Jones County, and flows NE into Craven County, where it enters Cove Creek.

label: Grassy Branch
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows NE into Rock Creek.

label: Grassy Branch
description: rises in W Cleveland County and flows NE into First Broad River.

label: Grassy Branch
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows NW into Pigeon River.

label: Grassy Branch
description: rises in NW Macon County and flows SW into Queens Creek.

label: Grassy Branch
description: rises in E Swain County and flows NW into Raven Fork.

label: Grassy Branch
description: rises in SE Swain County and flows N into Connelly Creek.

label: Grassy Creek
description: rises in N Alexander County and flows S and W into Lower Little River.

label: Grassy Creek
description: community in NE Ashe County. Settled about 1788.

label: Grassy Creek
description: rises in Grayson County, Va., and flows SE into Ashe County, where it enters North Fork New River.

label: Grassy Creek
description: rises in S Ashe County and flows S approx. 4 mi. into South Fork New River near the Watauga County line.

label: Grassy Creek
description: rises in W Granville County and flows NE into Kerr Lake.

label: Grassy Creek
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows SW into Henderson County, where it enters Broad River.

label: Grassy Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows SE into West Fork Tuckasegee River.

label: Grassy Creek
description: rises in W Madison County and flows NE into French Broad River.

label: Grassy Creek
description: rises in NE Moore County and flows NE into Deep River. Appears in local records as early as 1747 and on the MacRae map, 1833.

label: Grassy Creek
description: rises in E Surry County and flows S into Yadkin River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Grassy Creek
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows W into Little River.

label: Grassy Creek
description: rises in SW Henderson County and flows W into Transylvania County, where it enters Little River.

label: Grassy Creek
description: rises in N Union County and flows NE into Rocky River.

label: Grassy Creek
description: rises in E Watauga County and flows SE into South Fork New River.

label: Grassy Creek Township
description: NE Ashe County.

label: Grassy Gap
description: N Cherokee County in the Unicoi Mountains.

label: Grassy Gap
description: SE Clay County on Chunky Gal Mountain.

label: Grassy Gap
description: N Mitchell County between Grassy Knob and Right Fork Bean Creek.

label: Grassy Gap
description: on Graham-Swain county line between Grassy Top and Tyre Knob.

label: Grassy Knob
description: N Buncombe County between Salton Gap and Frosty Knob.

label: Grassy Knob
description: NW Buncombe County NE of High Knob.

label: Grassy Knob
description: central Caldwell County.

label: Grassy Knob
description: N Haywood County between Pigeon River and Wilkins Creek.

label: Grassy Knob
description: NW Iredell County. Now covered with trees, but apparently grassland when first discovered by settlers. The first Baptist church in the county was organized at its base in 1789, and an old Masonic lodge exists in the community nearby.

label: Grassy Knob
description: S Jackson County between Round Mountain and Whitewater River.

label: Grassy Knob
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Grassy Knob
description: central Macon County at the head of Poindexter Branch.

label: Grassy Knob
description: N Madison County between Shelton Laurel Creek and Spillcorn Creek.

label: Grassy Knob
description: a peak on Grassy Mountain on the McDowell-Mitchell county line. Alt. approx. 2,020.

label: Grassy Knob
description: N Mitchell County between Grassy Gap and Rich Branch.

label: Grassy Knob
description: central Watauga County on the E slope of Rich Mountain.

label: Grassy Mountain
description: SW Henderson County near Grassy Creek. Alt. 3,678.

label: Grassy Ridge Bald
description: on the Avery-Mitchell county line. Alt. 6,200-6,300.

label: Grassy Top
description: on the Cherokee County, N.C.-Monroe County, Tenn., line in the Unicoi Mountains. Alt. 4,979.

label: Grassy Top
description: on the Graham-Swain county line between The Jump-up and Grassy Gap.

label: Graveyard Ridge
description: W central Clay County in the Tusquitee Mountains, runs N and S along the Hiwassee River.

label: Grays Branch
description: rises in SW Caswell County and flows SE into Stony Creek.

label: Grays Creek
description: rises in SW Rutherford County and flows W into Broad River.

label: Grays Creek
description: rises in E Wilkes County and flows NE into Yadkin River. Named for James Gray, pre-Revolutionary War settler there.

label: Greasy Branch
description: rises in W Madison County and flows E into Spring Creek.

label: Greasy Creek
description: rises in NE Alexander County and flows E into South Yadkin River.

label: Greasy Creek
description: rises in central Clay County in Winchester Cove and flows NW into Tusquitee Creek.

label: Greasy Creek
description: rises in SW Clay County and flows SW into Brasstown Creek.

label: Greasy Creek
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows S into Big Rock Creek.

label: Great Branch
description: rises in E Beaufort County and flows E into Pungo River.

label: Great Branch
description: rises in S Nash County and flows E into Tar River.

label: Great Creek
description: tidal creek in Jarrett Bay, SE Carteret County.

label: Great Falls
description: on the Yadkin River a short distance S of The Narrows on the Montgomery-Stanly county line.

label: Great Island
description: in SE Bertie County between Cashie River and Middle River, formed in part by the Thoroughfare. The largest of a group of 9 islands, it measures approx. 4¾ mi. long and 2½ mi. wide. See also Purchace Islands.

label: Great Island
description: approx. 200 acres of high land located in North River Pocosin, E Camden County about 2 mi. E of Alder Branch and near the headwaters of Hunting Creek. No longer inhabited, but at one time as many as 8 families lived there.

label: Great Island
description: in Core Sound near Core Banks in E Carteret County.

label: Great Island
description: a small marshy island in the Neuse River in SE Craven County.

label: Great Island
description: in the waters of Pamlico Sound off the W coast of Hatteras Island, E Dare County SW of the community of Waves.

label: Great Island
description: S Hyde County in Pamlico Sound, 25-30 acres in area. Appears as Gul Island on the Collet map, 1770. See also Abigails Islands.

label: Great Marsh
description: tidal marsh covering the W portion of Knotts Island, NE Currituck County.

label: Great Swamp
description: swamplands covering most of central Currituck County and extending into E Camden County.

label: Great Swamp
description: rises in Grindle Pocosin in N Pitt County and flows S into Johnsons Mill Run.

label: Great Swamp
description: rises in E Johnston County, flows NE across NW Wayne County and into S Wilson County, where it enters Black Creek.

label: Great Swamp
description: in Beaufort, Martin, and Washington Counties between the Roanoke and Pamlico Rivers.

label: Green Cove
description: valley of Nichols Branch in S Macon County.

label: Green Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows NW into Panthertown Creek.

label: Green Creek
description: rises in SW Jackson County on the S slope of Whiteside Mountain and flows SE into Chattooga River.

label: Green Creek
description: rises in E Mitchell County and flows W into Little Rock Creek.

label: Green Creek
description: rises in E Pamlico County and flows S into Broad Creek.

label: Green Gap
description: in central Graham County at the head of Mountain Creek.

label: Green Gap
description: on Yellow Creek Mountains in N Graham County S of Fontana Village.

label: Green Hill
description: S Watauga County N of the community of Green Park.

label: Green Knob
description: S Haywood County in the middle of Fork Ridge.

label: Green Knob
description: on the Haywood-Transylvania county line between Bennett Gap and Pisgah Ridge. Alt. 5,150.

label: Green Level
description: community in NE Alamance County. School by the name in place by 1934. Inc. 1990.

label: Green Mountain
description: a range extending from central into NE Caldwell County. Alt. from 2,000 to 2,330. Indian name was Oawahua Indian Grave Gap there is the site of Indian burials. Indians lived on the top of the range.

label: Green Mountain
description: N Henderson County between Kyles Creek and Piney Mountain.

label: Green Mountain
description: N Jackson County between Hornbuckle Creek and Open Branch.

label: Green Mountain
description: extends N in NE Yancey County from near the head of Shoal Creek to Toe River. Alt. approx. 4,500.

label: Green Point
description: NE Carteret County at mouth of Lewis Creek on E side of Cedar Island.

label: Green River
description: rises in SW Henderson County and flows NE into Polk County, where it turns SE to enter Broad River on the Polk-Rutherford county line. Lake Summit in Henderson County and Lake Adger in Polk County are on Green River. The Peter Guice Bridge on Interstate 26 across the river is the second-highest bridge in the eastern United States after the New River Gorge Bridge in West Virginia.

label: Green Valley
description: the valley through which Round Hill Branch flows in NW Buncombe County.

label: Greens Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows E into Savannah Creek.

label: Greens Creek
description: rises in SE Pamlico County and flows E into Neuse River. Appears as Powel's Creek on the Lawson map, 1709. Soon afterward it came to be known as Farnifold Green's Creek for Furnifold Green, who had a grant for 1,700 acres there in 1707. Green was killed by the Tuscarora Indians in 1714.

label: Greens Creek
description: rises in SE Polk County and flows NE into Whiteoak Creek.

label: Greens Creek Township
description: W Jackson County.

label: Greenwood Township
description: former township in S Lee County, now township no. 1.

label: Greer Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows SW into Twentymile Creek.

label: Greer Creek
description: rises in S central Henderson County and flows NW into Mud Creek.

label: Gregory Branch
description: rises in E Cherokee County and flows NW into Pipes Branch.

label: Griffins Township
description: SE Martin County.

label: Grindstone Knob
description: E Macon County at the head of Indian Camp Creek.

label: Grog Creek
description: rises in E Rutherford County and flows S into Cleveland County, where it enters Sandy Run Creek.

label: Grovemont
description: community in SE Buncombe County N of Swannanoa.

label: Guilford
description: community in S central Beaufort County.

label: Gulf Branch
description: rises in NW Burke County and flows SW into Linville River.

label: Gum Branch
description: rises in SW Gates County and flows NE into Taylor Millpond.

label: Gum Branch
description: rises in W Mecklenburg County and flows W into Long Creek.

label: Gum Branch
description: rises in SE Wilson County and flows NW into Whiteoak Swamp.

label: Gum Swamp
description: SE Beaufort and NW Pamlico Counties.

label: Gum Swamp
description: rises in W Columbus County and flows SE to join Beaverdam Swamp in forming Monie Swamp.

label: Gum Swamp
description: rises in NW Jones County W of the town of Dover and flows NW into Craven County, where it enters Tracey Swamp. Formerly both were known as Gum Swamp. Two Civil War engagements took place on Gum Swamp, one on April 28, 1863, and the other on May 22, 1863. The first engagement is called by various names, including Wise's (Wyse's) Crossroads, Dover Crossroads, and First Gum Swamp.

label: Gum Swamp
description: rises in E Duplin County and flows SW into Limestone Creek.

label: Gum Swamp
description: rises in NE Pender County and flows S into Angola Creek.

label: Gum Swamp
description: rises in W Pitt County and flows SE into Swift Creek.

label: Gum Swamp
description: rises in S Hoke County and flows SE into Robeson County, where it enters Lumber River.

label: Gum Swamp Creek
description: rises in N Lenoir County and flows SW into Falling Creek. Name appears in local records dating from before the Revolution. Named for sweet gum trees in the area; sometimes locally called Sweetgum Swamp.

label: Hagaman
description: community in N central Caldwell County. Named for Hagaman family, large landowners in the vicinity.

label: Hallsborough
description: was authorized to be laid out in SE Surry County at the junction of Little Yadkin and Yadkin Rivers in 1809 on the land of John Hall. There is no evidence that the town was ever laid out.

label: Hamilton Township
description: NW Martin County.

label: Hampton
description: former community in SW Granville County served by post office, 1879-1906. Was located near Durham-Granville county line and dated from the nineteenth century. The site now lies within the Butner area. Ceased to exist when Camp Butner was created. See also Butner.

label: Hampton Branch
description: rises in NW Macon County and flows S into Partridge Creek.

label: Hampton Branch
description: rises in E Madison County and flows SW into Puncheon Fork Creek.

label: Hanging Rock
description: on the Avery-Watauga county line at the SW end of Hanging Rock Ridge. Alt. 5,237. Known by the Cherokee Indians as Yonah-wayah (bear's paw).

label: Happy Home
description: community in NE Rockingham County named for local Christian church organized in 1884.

label: Harbor Island
description: NE Carteret County in Core Sound midway between Chainshot Island and Wainwright Island. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733. Once horseshoe-shaped, but storms have caused erosion, and much of it is now washed away. The site of fishermen's huts and anchorage. See also Hunting Quarter Sound.

label: Hardin
description: community in NE Cherokee County NW of Andrews.

label: Hardy Creek
description: a short stream in N central Carteret County flowing E into South River.

label: Harper Creek
description: is formed in SE Avery County by the junction of North Harper and South Harper creeks. It flows E into Caldwell County, where it enters Wilsons Creek.

label: Harris
description: community in central Jackson County served by office, 1892-1911. Also known as Harris Mine.

label: Harris Creek
description: rises in S Avery County and flows W into North Toe River.

label: Harris Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Valley River.

label: Harris Creek
description: rises in N McDowell County and flows E into Tom Creek.

label: Harris Creek
description: rises in W Onslow County and flows E into Southwest Creek.

label: Harris Crossroads
description: community in S Franklin County.

label: Harris Millpond
description: S Martin County on Beargrass Swamp.

label: Harris Mountain
description: on the McDowell-Rutherford county line. Named for John W. Harris, one of the commissioners who surveyed the line between the two counties about 1845.

label: Harris Top
description: peak on Payne Mountain in SW Cherokee County.

label: Harris Township
description: former township in S Franklin County, now township no. 2.

label: Harrisburg
description: community in SW Cabarrus County. First Known as Harris Depot. Alt. 610.

label: Harrison Creek
description: rises in S Pender County and flows NW into Merricks Creek. Named for Charles Harrison, who owned property in the vicinity as early as 1739.

label: Harrison Gap
description: on the Graham County, N.C.-Monroe County, Tenn., line.

label: Harvey
description: community in E Lincoln County served by post office, 1891-1903.

label: Haw Branch
description: rises in central Avery County and flows N into North Toe River.

label: Haw Branch
description: rises in NW Beaufort County and flows SW into Tranters Creek.

label: Haw Branch
description: rises in SW Nash County and flows S into Turkey Creek.

label: Haw Creek
description: rises in central Buncombe County and flows SW into Swannanoa River. Named in 1860 for the black haw bushes growing along its banks.

label: Haw Gap
description: central Avery County.

label: Haw River
description: rises in NE Forsyth County and flows NE and SE through Guilford and Rockingham Counties and across Alamance and Chatham Counties to join Deep River on the Chatham-Lee county line to form Cape Fear River. It is approx. 130 mi. in length. In 1709 John Lawson called it the Hau River and said that it was named for the Sissipahau Indians, who lived along its banks. Appears as Saxapahaw River on the Moseley map, 1733, but the Collet map, 1770, uses its present name. The town of Haywood, at the junction of Deep and Haw Rivers, was one of six sites suggested in 1788 for the location of the state capital.

label: Haw River Township
description: former township in central Alamance County. Now township no. 13.

label: Hawk Branch
description: N Yancey County, is formed by the junction of South Fork Hawk Creek and Middle Fork Hawk Creek and flows W into Cane River. Sometimes known locally as Hog Branch.

label: Hawk Knob
description: N Cherokee County on NW end of Chestnut Mountain in the Unicoi Mountains.

label: Hawkins Branch
description: rises in S Pender County and flows SW into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Hawkins Branch
description: rises in E Transylvania County and flows SE into Little River.

label: Hayesville
description: town and county seat, central Clay County on Hiwassee River. Alt. 1,893. Inc. 1891. Named for George W. Hayes (1804-64), a member of the General Assembly who was instrumental in the formation of the county. Fort Hembree, ¾ mi. nw, was one of the forts at which Gen. Winfield Scott, in command of U.S. forces, gathered the Cherokee Indians before moving them W in 1838. Produces lumber and apparel.

label: Haywood Gap
description: in Newfound Mountain on the Buncombe-Haywood county line between Rocky Knob and Dry Mountain.

label: Hazel
description: former town in central Buncombe County at or near West Asheville. Inc. 1891 but soon became inactive in municipal affairs. Now within the city limits of Asheville.

label: Hebron
description: community in NW Granville County.

label: Hector Creek
description: rises in S Harnett County and flows S on the Moore-Cumberland county line into Little River. Named for Hector McNeill, an early settler.

label: Hell Swamp
description: E Beaufort County N of Pungo Creek.

label: Hemphill Creek
description: rises in central Haywood County and flows E into Jonathans Creek. Named for an early settler in area.

label: Henderson
description: former town in W Montgomery County at the junction of Yadkin and Uwharrie Rivers. Inc. 1794; "re-surveyed" in 1813. Was the site of the courthouse from soon after the establishment of the town until about 1816. By the 1850s Henderson no longer appeared on maps of the state. See also Tindallsville.

label: Henrietta
description: former community in S Edgecombe County. Now only a railroad crossing.

label: Hensley Branch
description: rises in N Madison County near Big Knob and flows SE on the W side of Ephraim Hensley Mountain into Shelton Laurel Creek.

label: Hensley Ridge
description: N McDowell County, extends E from Betsy Ridge. Alt. approx. 2,300.

label: Henson Creek
description: rises in W Avery County and flows SE into North Toe River.

label: Hickory
description: city in NW Catawba County. Alt. 1,163. Inc. 1863 as Hickory Tavern. Named for a log tavern built at the site in the 1850s. Name changed to Hickory, 1873. West Hickory, inc. as Berryville in 1895, is now within the limits of Hickory. Highland, inc. 1905, whose charter was repealed in 1931, is also now a part of Hickory. Highland was named for Highland Academy, located within its limits. Lenoir-Rhyne University now occupies site of former Highland Academy. Produces hosiery, textiles, furniture, electronics, fabricated metals, primary metals, and lumber.

label: Hickory Branch
description: rises in N central Avery County and flows S to join Whitehead Creek before flowing into Elk River.

label: Hickory Branch
description: rises in SW Cherokee County and flows SE into Persimmon Creek.

label: Hickory Cove
description: S Swain County, extends NE between Marr Branch and Brush Creek.

label: Hickory Cove
description: W Swain County between Sandy Gap Branch and Gunlock Ridge.

label: Hickory Creek
description: rises in SE Caldwell County and flows S into Upper Little River.

label: Hickory Creek
description: rises in S Guilford County and flows S into Deep River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Hickory Flat Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows S into Oconaluftee River.

label: Hickory Gap
description: near the junction of the Buncombe-Madison-Yancey county lines. Alt. approx. 3,550.

label: Hickory Gap
description: S Graham County between Little Snowbird Creek and Teeseteska Ridge.

label: Hickory Grove
description: community in SW Chatham County.

label: Hickory Grove
description: community in E Mecklenburg County. A post office was est. there as early as 1828.

label: Hickory Grove
description: community in E Wake County.

label: Hickory Knob
description: at the junction of the Alexander, Caldwell, and Wilkes county lines.

label: Hickory Knob
description: SW Burke County.

label: Hickory Knob
description: on the Cherokee-Macon county line.

label: Hickory Knob
description: E Macon County between Laurel Creek and North Prong Ellijay Creek.

label: Hickory Mountain
description: W Chatham County approx. 5 mi. E of Siler City.

label: Hickory Nut Gap
description: central Avery County.

label: Hickory Nut Gap
description: on the Buncombe-Henderson county line between Tater Knob and Ferguson Peak. Alt. 2,878. Originally known as Sherrill's Gap. One of two gaps (the other being Swannanoa Gap) through which early settlers and travelers from the E reached the Asheville plateau.

label: Hickory Point
description: SE Beaufort County on the S side of Pamlico River at the mouth of South Creek.

label: Hicks Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Junaluska Creek.

label: Hicks Branch
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows NE into Pigeon River.

label: High Falls

label: High Falls
description: N Transylvania County in South Fork Mills River. Height of the falls is 30 ft.

label: High Falls
description: SE Transylvania County in Little River near Cedar Mountain. Height of the falls is 75 ft.

label: High Knob
description: N Buncombe County between High Swan and Rich Knob.

label: High Knob
description: NE Buncombe County W of Pigpen Knob.

label: High Knob
description: NW Buncombe County between Robinson Mountain and Grassy Knob.

label: High Knob
description: mountain in Wilson Ridge, NW Caldwell County. Alt. 2,686.

label: High Knob
description: S Macon County between Deer Gap and Beasley Gap.

label: High Knob
description: N Madison County at the head of Duckmill Branch.

label: High Knob
description: E Mitchell County between Ivy Knob and Lightwood Mountain.

label: High Knob
description: N central Transylvania County at the E end of Shutin Ridge.

label: High Knob
description: S Yancey County near the head of Banks Creek.

label: High Peak
description: central Burke County. Alt. 2,184.

label: High Peak
description: on the Burke-Rutherford county line in the South Mountains. Alt. approx. 2,720.

label: High Peak
description: NE Cherokee County on the head of Tom Thumb Creek in the Snowbird Mountains. Alt. approx. 3,800.

label: High Peak
description: on the Buncombe-Henderson county line.

label: High Peak
description: SE Watauga County between Joes Creek and Triplett Creek.

label: High Peak
description: N Yancey County between the heads of Seng Branch and Bailey Branch. Alt. approx. 4,400.

label: High Peak

label: High Point
description: S peak of Deaver View Mountain in central Buncombe County.

label: High Point
description: peak in W Jackson County between Nation Creek and Rocky Branch.

label: High Rock
description: community in S Davidson County on Yadkin River. Alt. 584.

label: High Rock
description: mountain in central Madison County between Hunter Creek and Brush Creek at the N end of High Rock Ridge. Alt. 3,555.

label: High Rock Lake

label: High Rock Ridge
description: central Madison County between Brush Creek and Walnut Creek.

label: High Rocks
description: peak in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on Welch Ridge. Alt. 5,188.

label: High Shoals
description: community on South Fork Catawba River in N Gaston County. Settled about 1750. Named for high, rocky shoal in the river. Alt. 724.

label: High Top
description: SE Buncombe County in the Blue Ridge Mountains between High Windy and Lakey Knob.

label: High Top
description: N Graham County on the E end of Yellow Creek Mountains.

label: High Top
description: central Haywood County between Messer Branch and Sugar Cove.

label: High Top
description: S Haywood County at the head of Big Branch.

label: High Top
description: W Jackson County at the head of Brook Branch.

label: High Top
description: S Macon County between Low Gap and Pine Knob.

label: Highfall Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows N into Valley River.

label: Hills Creek
description: rises in SW Beaufort County and flows N into Pamlico River.

label: Hills Creek
description: rises in E Rutherford County and flows SW into Second Broad River.

label: Hillsdale
description: community in NE Davie County. Alt. 807.

label: Hodges Creek
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows NE into McDowell County, where it enters Crooked Creek.

label: Hodges Creek
description: rises in SE Hertford County and flows SE into Chowan River.

label: Hodges Gap
description: S central Watauga County between Laurel Creek and Hodges Creek.

label: Hog Branch
description: rises in NW Ashe County and flows S into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Hog Branch
description: rises in W Orange County and flows S into Cane Creek.

label: Hog Island

label: Hog Island
description: swampy island in central Craven County formed by Neuse River on the E and Bachelor Creek and The Gut on the w. Formerly known as Leaches Island for George M. Leach, who owned the island in 1804, and appears with that name on the Price map, 1808, the MacRae map, 1833, and the U.S. Coast Survey map, 1865. Approx. 3½ mi. long and 1 mi. wide at its widest point.

label: Hog Island
description: in Pamlico Sound near Hog Island Point on the E mainland of Hyde County.

label: Hog Island Point
description: S point of Hog Island in NE Carteret County.

label: Hogan Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows S into Junaluska Creek.

label: Hogans Creek
description: rises in NW Caswell County and flows NE into Dan River.

label: Hogans Creek
description: rises in N Guilford County and flows N into SW Rockingham County and into Dan River.

label: Hogback Mountain
description: N Graham County between Stecoah Creek and Sawyer Creek, extends NE from Big Garland Gap to Wildcat Gap. Alt. 5,200.

label: Hogback Mountain
description: NW Henderson County at the head of Foster Mill Creek.

label: Hogback Mountain
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line. Alt. 4,950.

label: Hogback Mountain
description: E Macon County between Walnut and Buck Creeks.

label: Hogpen Branch
description: rises in SW Buncombe County near Hogpen Gap and flows NW into Glady Fork.

label: Hogpen Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Taylor Creek.

label: Hogpen Gap
description: SW Buncombe County S of Young Pisgah Mountain.

label: Hogpen Gap
description: central Cherokee County between West Prong Grape Creek and Grape Creek.

label: Holden Cove
