description: stream, rises in S Haywood County and flows NE into Shining Creek.

label: South River
description: is formed on the Cumberland-Sampson county line by the junction of Black River and East Mingo Branch. It flows SE along the Cumberland-Sampson and Bladen-Sampson county lines into Black River near the Pender County line.

label: South River
description: community on the W side of South River near its mouth, N Carteret County.

label: South River
description: rises in N Carteret County and flows N approx. 9½ mi. into Neuse River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Southwest Creek
description: rises in N Carteret County and flows NE into South River.

label: Southwest Creek
description: rises in SW Lenoir County and flows NE into Neuse River. Appears as Salmon Creek on the Moseley map, 1733; called Canterbury Creek by Governor Arthur Dobbs; and appears as Southwest Creek on the Collet map, 1770. Scene of 1863 Battle of Wyse Fork, which see.

label: Spanish Oak Branch
description: rises in W central Transylvania County and flows S into Catheys Creek.

label: Spencer
description: town in E Rowan County. Construction of shops for the Southern Railway was begun there in 1896. Inc. in 1901 and named for Samuel Spencer (1847-1906), president of Southern Railway. Whiteheads Mill appears on Grants Creek near present site of Spencer on the Collet map, 1770. Alt. 747. Home to North Carolina Transportation Museum, a State Historic Site.

label: Spencer Mountain
description: E central Gaston County. Broadcast towers are there. Named for Zachariah Spencer, local Loyalist (Tory) who was captured during Revolutionary War, tried, and condemned to be shot. He turned "Whig," promising allegiance to the new republic; having no Bible, he took an oath on an almanac and was released. Alt. 1,304.

label: Spice Cove Branch
description: rises near Louis Ray Knob in NE Buncombe County and flows NW through Spice Cove into North Fork Ivy Creek.

label: Spring Branch
description: rises in E Craven County and flows SE into Broad Creek.

label: Spring Branch
description: rises in S Greene County and flows E into Tyson Marsh.

label: Spring Branch
description: rises in E Johnston County and flows SW into Little River.

label: Spring Branch
description: rises in S Lenoir County and flows NW into Southwest Creek.

label: Spring Branch
description: rises in NE Onslow County and flows NE into Grants Creek.

label: Spring Branch
description: rises in central Wake County and flows NW into House Creek.

label: Spring Creek
description: rises in W Alexander County and flows SW into Lower Little River.

label: Spring Creek
description: community in SE Beaufort County.

label: Spring Creek
description: rises in SE Brunswick County and flows SE into Walden Creek.

label: Spring Creek
description: rises in NW Columbus County near the Bladen County line and flows NE into Horsepen Creek.

label: Spring Creek
description: community in W Madison County on Spring Creek.

label: Spring Creek
description: rises in N Mitchell County and flows SE into Big Rock Creek.

label: Spring Creek
description: rises in E Pamlico County and flows NE into Bonner Bay.

label: Spring Garden
description: community in NW Craven County on Neuse River. A farming area that has retained the name of the plantation of Governor Richard Dobbs Spaight.

label: Spring Hill
description: community in E Halifax County. Alt. 70.

label: Spring Hope
description: community in E Craven County.

label: Spring Mountain
description: NE Alexander County. Alt. 1,620.

label: Spring Mountain
description: SW Buncombe County NE of Twelve O'Clock Top.

label: Springfield
description: community in W Scotland County on Gum Swamp Creek.

label: Squirrel Branch
description: rises in SW Gaston County and flows NE into Crowders Creek.

label: Squirrel Branch
description: rises in N Guilford County and flows E into Reedy Fork Creek.

label: Squirrel Creek
description: rises in central Avery County and flows W into North Toe River.

label: St. George's Parish
description: Church of England, Anson County, est. in 1750 when the county was formed and coextensive with it. Composed of 969 white taxable inhabitants in 1767, who were described as "in general poor & incapable to support a Minister."

label: St. George's Parish
description: Church of England, Northampton County, est. 1758 when Northwest Parish was divided. The W part became St. George's and, after 1759, when the E part of Northampton became a part of Hertford County, the parish was coextensive with the county. In 1767 there were 1,600 white taxables living in the parish. Records of St. George's Parish, 1773-1814, are in the North Carolina State Archives, Raleigh.

label: St. John's Parish
description: Church of England, Carteret County, probably was est. with the formation of the county in 1722. It is mentioned as early as 1724. Coextensive with the county. In 1767 there were 470 white taxables in the parish. The vestry book of St. John's Parish, 1742-43, in 3 volumes, is in the North Carolina State Archives, Raleigh.

label: St. John's Parish
description: Church of England, Onslow County, was est. in 1734 with the formation of the county and coextensive with it. In 1767 the parish had 716 white taxables described as "willing to receive tho’ hardly capable of making provisions for Minister."

label: St. John's Parish
description: Church of England, Granville (later Bute) County, est. in 1746 with the formation of Granville County. Coextensive with the county. In 1758 the parish was divided, creating Granville Parish in the W; St. John's Parish was in the E. Bute County, created in 1764, and the parish were coextensive. In 1767 there were 1,299 white taxables in St. John's Parish. Warren and Franklin Counties were formed from Bute County in 1779.

label: St. Johns
description: community in SW Hertford County at the head of Chapel Branch. Mentioned in local records as early as 1722. Douglas Ordinary appears on the Collet map, 1770, at the site.

label: St. Martin's Parish
description: Church of England, Bladen County, est. in 1734 when the county was formed and coextensive with the county. The parish had 791 white taxables in 1767, described as being "in middling circumstances."

label: St. Martin's Parish
description: Church of England, Martin County, est. 1774 with the formation of the county and coextensive with it.

label: Stacy
description: community in NE Carteret County on a point of land extending into Core Sound from the mainland. Was called Piney Point prior to 1888.

label: Stallings
description: community in E Franklin County. Alt. 347. Est. 1880. Named for J. M. Stallings, who est. a cotton gin and sawmill there.

label: Stanley Creek
description: rises in NE Gaston County and flows SE into Dutchmans Creek.

label: Star Branch
description: rises near Oaks Knob, W Avery County, and flows NE into Roaring Creek.

label: Starkeys Creek
description: rises in W Carteret County and flows S approx. 3 mi. into Pettivers Creek. Named for John Starkey, colonial treasurer and member of the Assembly.

label: Staunton
description: community in W Wilkes County on North Prong Lewis Fork Creek.

label: Steel Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows SW into Little River.

label: Steep Hill Branch
description: rises in W Carteret County and flows W approx. 3 mi. into White Oak River.

label: Stepps Gap
description: on Kings Mountain on Cleveland-Gaston county line. Alt. 1,040.

label: Stevens
description: community in W Union County served by post office, 1865-1905.

label: Stevens Creek
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows NE into Pigeon River.

label: Stevens Creek
description: rises in SE Mecklenburg County and flows S into Union County, where it enters Duck Creek.

label: Stevens Mill
description: community in NW Union County on Goose Creek served by post office, 1852-68. Formerly called Stevens.

label: Stewart Creek
description: rises SE of the town of Warsaw in W Duplin County and flows SW into Six Runs Creek in E Sampson County. Appears as Stewards Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Stewart Creek
description: rises in N Mecklenburg County and flows S to join Taggart Creek in forming Sugar Creek.

label: Stewarts Creek
description: rises in W Cumberland County and flows SE into Beaver Creek.

label: Stewarts Creek
description: rises in E Hoke County and flows SE onto Cumberland-Hoke county line and into Rockfish Creek.

label: Stewarts Creek
description: rises in W Forsyth County and flows SE into Muddy Creek. Until some time prior to 1762, it was known as Tomahawk Branch. In that year, Joseph Stewart settled near its banks, and it presumably took his name. It appears as Stewarts Creek on the Collet map, 1770, but small streams flowing into it are still known as Tomahawk Creek and Little Tomahawk Creek.

label: Stewarts Creek
description: rises in S Harnett County and flows SE into Little River.

label: Stillhouse Branch
description: rises in S Avery County and flows NW into Whiteoak Branch.

label: Stillhouse Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SE into Valley River.

label: Stillhouse Branch
description: rises in N Macon County and flows W into Rose Creek.

label: Stillhouse Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SW into Tessentee Creek.

label: Stone Creek
description: rises in SW Henderson County and flows SE into Rock Creek.

label: Stone Mountain
description: on the Alleghany-Wilkes county line. Alt. 3,879.

label: Stone Mountain
description: SE Buncombe County N of Jarvis Mountain. Alt. 3,700.

label: Stone Mountain
description: W Transylvania County S of Butter Gap. Alt. 3,698.

label: Stone Mountain
description: NE Watauga County E of Grassy Creek.

label: Stoney Creek
description: rises in S Hertford County and flows in an inverted arc into Ahoskie Swamp. Stony Bridge appears on the Moseley map, 1733, as spanning the stream S of the present town of Ahoskie. Appears as Stony Creek Bridge on the Collet map, 1770; as Bonner Bridge on the MacRae map, 1833; and as Jernigan's Bridge on the soil survey map, 1916.

label: Stony Creek
description: rises in N central Bertie County and flows N into Hertford County, where it enters Ahoskie Creek.

label: Stony Creek
description: is formed in NE Buncombe County by the junction of Carter and Mineral Creeks. It flows N into Dillingham Creek.

label: Stony Creek
description: community in S Caswell County. A post office operated there, 1836-1905.

label: Stony Creek
description: rises in E Lee County and flows NW into Lick Creek.

label: Stony Creek
description: is formed in W Nash County by the junction of Big and Little Peachtree Creeks and flows SE into Tar River. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Stony Creek
description: rises in E Orange County and flows NE into Eno River.

label: Stony Creek
description: rises in E Surry County and flows SW into Ararat River.

label: Stony Creek
description: rises in central Wayne County and flows SW into Neuse River. Named in local records as early as 1756. The name appears as Rocky Creek on the Price map, 1808.

label: Stony Creek Township
description: E Nash County.

label: Stony Fork
description: community in SW Buncombe County on Stony Fork near the mouth of McKinney Creek. Alt. 2,368.

label: Stony Fork
description: rises in SW Buncombe County near Little Pisgah Mountain and flows N into Warren Creek.

label: Stony Fork
description: rises in W Johnston County and flows SE into Hannah Creek.

label: Stony Knob
description: N Buncombe County between Wagner Branch and Reems Creek.

label: Stony Knob
description: on the Buncombe-Henderson county line between High Top and Luther Gap.

label: Stony Mountain
description: E Madison County between Chandler Creek and the head of California Creek.

label: Stony Point
description: community in SE Alexander County. Site settled 1789. Stony Point post office est. 1826 but operated in different homes, stores, etc., within a radius of about 2 mi. In 1887 a railroad station, Sloan or Sloans Station, was opened, but the community soon came to be known by the official post office name, Stony Point. Named for rocky formation at the site. Alt. 1,090.

label: Straight Creek
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows NW into North Fork Ivy Creek.

label: Strawberry Knob
description: on the Graham County, N.C.-Monroe County, Tenn., line.

label: Stubblefield
description: community in NW Caswell County. Named for a local family.

label: Stumpy Point
description: peninsula extending S from the E mainland of Dare County into Pamlico Sound and Stumpy Point Bay. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Sugar Cove
description: SE Clay County.

label: Sugar Cove
description: S Haywood County on the head of Right Hand Prong [Pigeon River].

label: Sugar Cove Creek
description: rises near Tellico Bald in N Macon County and flows NE into Tellico Creek.

label: Sugar Cove Gap
description: on the Haywood-Madison county line.

label: Sugar Creek
description: rises in N Buncombe County near Watershed Ridge and flows N into Ivy Creek.

label: Sugar Creek
description: rises in NE Davie County and flows SE 2 mi. into Cedar Creek W of Smith Grove. Referred to in early local records as Sugar Tree Creek.

label: Sugar Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows NE into Caney Fork.

label: Sugar Creek
description: rises in S Lee County and flows NW into Pocket Creek.

label: Sugar Fork
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows SE into North Fork [Swannanoa River].

label: Sugar Fork
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows NE into Greens Creek.

label: Sugar Fork
description: rises in NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park and flows 1.5 mi. SE into Haw Gap Branch.

label: Sugar Hollow
description: SE Buncombe County between Ashworth Creek and Reed Branch.

label: Sugar Loaf
description: mountain in N Alexander County. Named for its resemblance to an oldfashioned loaf of sugar.

label: Sugarloaf Creek
description: rises in E Henderson County and flows N into Reedy Patch Creek.

label: Sugarloaf Mountain
description: on the Henderson-Rutherford county line about 1 mi. NW from the coincident corners of Henderson, Polk, and Rutherford Counties. Alt. 3,965. The Indian name for the mountain was Salola (squirrel).

label: Sugarloaf Mountain
description: on the head of Sugarloaf Creek in N Jackson County.

label: Sugarloaf Mountain
description: N Madison County between Shelton Laurel Creek and Colvin Creek.

label: Sugarloaf Mountain
description: E Stanly County in Morrow Mountain State Park.

label: Sugartree Gap
description: on the Buncombe-Madison county line W of Campground Knob.

label: Sugartree Gap
description: on the Haywood-Swain county line.

label: Suggs Creek
description: rises in SE Edgecombe County and flows s, forming the Edgecombe-Pitt county line until it flows into the Tar River.

label: Sulphur Springs
description: community in central Buncombe County between Acton and Boswell.

label: Sulphur Springs
description: community in SE Montgomery County served by post office, 1869-1920.

label: Sulphur Springs
description: community in N Surry County on Ararat River. Formerly a popular resort.

label: Summit
description: community in NW Halifax County. Since the elevation is considerably higher than that of the surrounding region, Easter sunrise services are frequently held there. Alt. 312.

label: Summit
description: community in W Wilkes County between Lewis Fork Creek and North Prong Lewis Fork Creek.

label: Sunnyside
description: community in NW Cabarrus County.

label: Sunnyside
description: community in W Gaston County.

label: Sunnyside
description: community in NW Pender County.

label: Sutton
description: community in S Duplin County.

label: Swamp Creek
description: rises in SE Bertie County and flows NE into Cashie River.

label: Swan Creek
description: rises in E Pamlico County and flows SE into Pamlico Sound.

label: Swan Island
description: NE Currituck Sound 2 mi. S of Knotts Island, N Currituck County. Approx. ½ by ¼ mi. in size. Site of Swan Island Club, duck-and goose-shooting club owned by wealthy Bostonians.

label: Swan Point
description: the NW point of Cedar Island in NE Carteret County.

label: Swannanoa Gap
description: in the Blue Ridge Mountains on the Buncombe-McDowell county line at the W end of Youngs Ridge. Lat. 35°37'20" N., long. 82°16'20" W. One of the two gaps (the other being Hickory Nut Gap) through which early settlers and travelers from the E reached the Asheville plateau. See also Black Mountain Gap.

label: Sweet Branch
description: rises in NW Swain County and flows S into Lake Cheoah.

label: Sweetwater Branch
description: rises in N central Henderson County and flows SE into North Fork.

label: Sweetwater Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows SE into French Broad River.

label: Sweetwater Branch
description: rises near Black Mountain in N Transylvania County and flows NE into South Fork Mills.

label: Sweetwater Creek
description: rises in W Clay County and flows SW and NW into Hiwassee River.

label: Sweetwater Gap
description: S Clay County between Kimsey Ridge and Ivy Top.

label: Swift Creek
description: name given Sandy Creek in Hilliardston community, N Nash County. Sandy Creek, which see, rises in SE Vance County. As Swift Creek, it flows SE across Nash County and into Edgecombe County, where it enters Tar River. Swift Creek appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Swift Creek
description: rises in S central Pitt County and flows SE into N Craven County, where it enters Neuse River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Swift Creek Township
description: former township in NW Edgecombe County, now township no. 7.

label: Swift Creek Township
description: S Pitt County.

label: Sycamore Creek
description: rises in central Franklin County and flows SW into Tar River.

label: Tar River
description: rises in W central Person County and flows SE through Granville, Franklin, Nash, Edgecombe, and Pitt Counties to Beaufort County, where it becomes the Pamlico River. It is 179 mi. long. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733, apparently for the first time; previously known as Pampticough and other spellings of the modern Pamlico. There are many explanations of the origin of the name. It may be from an Indian word, Tau, meaning "river of health"; named for the Taw River in Devonshire, England; or named because of the tar produced in the counties through which it flows.

label: Tarkiln Branch
description: rises in W Swain County and flows SE into Little Tennessee River.

label: Tarkiln Mountain
description: peak on Forge Mountain in W Henderson County.

label: Tater Hill
description: in S Macon County between Poplar Cove and Rocky Knob.

label: Tater Hill
description: in S Macon County between Rattlesnake Ridge and Licklog Gap.

label: Tatham Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW through Andrews into Valley River.

label: Taylor Bay
description: in Bogue Sound, W Carteret County S of community of Bogue.

label: Taylor Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Valley River.

label: Taylors Creek
description: rises in the W tip of Carteret County and flows SW approx. 1 mi. into White Oak River.

label: Taylors Creek
description: rises in SW Duplin County and flows SE into Duffs Creek.

label: Taylors Creek
description: rises in NW Franklin County and flows N into Tar River.

label: Taylors Creek
description: rises in E Gaston County and flows SE into Dutchmans Creek.

label: Taylorsville
description: town and county seat, central Alexander County. Settled 1847; inc. 1851. Probably named for Zachary Taylor (1784-1850), whose defeat of Santa Anna early in 1847 ended the war in N Mexico; Taylor was president of the United States, 1849-50. Alt. 1,247. Produces textiles, furniture, and paper boxes.

label: Taylorsville
description: an African American community in S Moore County. Named for Robert L. Taylor, educator, who founded a school and a store there in 1908.

label: Terrapin Creek
description: rises in E Catawba County and flows E into Catawba River.

label: Third Creek
description: rises in E Alexander County and flows SE across Iredell County and into Rowan County, where it enters Fourth Creek. It is the third creek in a series of creeks crossed by early settlers moving W from Salisbury. Appears on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Third Creek
description: See Cleveland.

label: Thomas Branch
description: rises in SW Macon County and flows NW into Nantahala River.

label: Thompson Branch
description: rises in E Macon County and flows S into Watauga Creek.

label: Thompson Township
description: former township in SE Alamance County, now township no. 9.

label: Thoroughfare
description: a waterway approx. 2 mi. long in SE Bertie County connecting Cashie and Roanoke Rivers.

label: Three Knobs
description: S Avery County.

label: Threemile Creek
description: rises in NW McDowell County near Little Switzerland and flows S into Armstrong Creek.

label: Thumb Swamp
description: NE Bladen County. Approx. 2 mi. long; drains W into Turnbull Creek.

label: Thunderstruck Knob
description: in E Yancey County at the E end of Bee Ridge.

label: Tilden
description: community in SE Yadkin County served by post office, 1897-1904.

label: Timber Ridge
description: mountain in E central Avery County.

label: Timber Ridge
description: SW Jackson County between Cashier Valley and Chattooga River.

label: Timber Ridge
description: S Macon County parallel to Gulf Branch.

label: Timber Ridge
description: NW McDowell County near the head of Armstrong Creek.

label: Tobacco Branch
description: rises in NE Graham County and flows NE into Wolf Creek.

label: Tom Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NE into Taylor Creek.

label: Tom Creek
description: rises in SE Buncombe County and flows SE into Broad River.

label: Tom Creek
description: rises in S Haywood County and flows N into West Fork Pigeon River.

label: Tom's Creek
description: rises in S Caswell County and flows S into Alamance County, where it enters Stony Creek.

label: Tomahawk Creek
description: rises in W Forsyth County and flows SE into Stewarts Creek, which see.

label: Toms Creek
description: rises in NE Henderson County and flows SE into Mill Creek.

label: Toms Creek
description: community in N McDowell County S of Woodlawn. Named for creek of the same name.

label: Toms Creek
description: rises in W McDowell County and flows SE into Catawba River. Toms Creek Falls are N of Marion.

label: Toms Creek
description: rises in W Orange County and flows SE into Cane Creek.

label: Toms Creek
description: rises in W Randolph County and flows NE and SE into Uwharrie River.

label: Toms Creek
description: rises in E Surry County and flows SW into Ararat River.

label: Toms Creek
description: rises in E Wake County and flows W into Neuse River.

label: Town Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows SW into Dillingham Creek.

label: Town Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW through Andrews into Valley River.

label: Town Creek
description: is formed in E central Brunswick County by the junction of Rattlesnake Branch and Lewis Swamp and flows SE into Cape Fear River just above Campbell Island. Named Indian Creek by William Hilton in 1663 but appears as Old Town Creek on the Moseley map, 1733. See also Charles Town.

label: Town Creek
description: rises in S central Carteret County and flows W into Newport River. It forms the N limits of the town of Beaufort.

label: Town Creek
description: rises in central Catawba County and flows SW into Clark Creek.

label: Town Creek
description: rises in S Montgomery County and flows SE into Little River.

label: Town Creek
description: rises in SE Nash County and flows SW across Wilson County into SW Edgecombe County, where it flows NE and SE into Tar River. Called Mallard Creek on Moseley map, 1733, but appears as Town Creek on Collet map, 1770.

label: Town Creek
description: rises in central Onslow County and flows NE into Farnell Bay. Land taken up along the river beginning about 1706.

label: Town Creek
description: rises in central Rockingham County and flows N into Dan River. Named for the fact that Lower Saura Town, which see, an Indian village, was near its mouth. Discovered by William Byrd and his surveying party in 1728.

label: Town Creek
description: rises in N Stanly County and flows S into Long Creek.

label: Town Creek
description: town in NE Wilson County near the stream of the same name. Inc. 1899, but long inactive in municipal affairs. A Baptist church there was est. in 1802.

label: Townsend
description: community in SE Cumberland County.

label: Trail Ridge
description: a twisting mountain ridge in N Clay County extending N from Tusquitee Ridge to Wolf Ridge.

label: Trail Ridge
description: NW Macon County between Long Branch and Otter Creek.

label: Trent Branch
description: rises in central Buncombe County and flows NE into Hominy Creek.

label: Trent River
description: rises in S Lenoir County and flows SE across Jones County and into Craven County, where it enters Neuse River at New Bern. Appears as Quoracks River on the Comberford map, 1657; apparently first called Trent River by John Lawson, 1709, probably for the river of that name in England. Appears as Trent River on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Triangle
description: community in E Lincoln County served by post office, 1878-1903. Settled 1902. Named for triangle formed by roads at the site.

label: Trinity
description: town in NW Randolph County. Union Institute, a school, was est. there in 1838. Located midway between the neighborhoods of Hopewell on the S and Springfield on the n, it took its name from the fact that it was expected to serve to unite the two. Twelve years later the school was reorganized as Trinity College, and the town took its name from the college. Inc. 1869. In 1892 the college moved to Durham, becoming Duke University in 1924.

label: Troublesome Creek
description: rises in N Guilford County and flows NE into Rockingham County, where it enters Haw River. Sometimes also known as Big Troublesome Creek.

label: Trout Creek
description: a slough in the W end of Bogue Sound, SW Carteret County. Named by fishermen for the trout caught there.

label: Trout Creek
description: rises in central Jackson County and flows W into West Fork Tuckasegee River.

label: Tuckahoe Creek
description: rises in NW Hoke County and flows NW into James Creek.

label: Tucker Creek
description: rises in S Craven County and flows NE into mouth of Slocum Creek.

label: Tull Creek
description: rises in central and E Currituck County and flows NW and NE into Tull Bay. Appears on the Collet map, 1770. Named for the Tull family, living there by 1710.

label: Turkey Branch
description: rises in W central Halifax County and flows E approx. 1½ mi. into Jacket Swamp.

label: Turkey Branch
description: rises in central Jackson County and flows NE into Tuckasegee River.

label: Turkey Cove
description: E Haywood County on the head of Cove Creek.

label: Turkey Cove
description: NW McDowell County.

label: Turkey Cove Gap
description: W Madison County between Turkey Cove Branch and East Fork Shut-in Creek.

label: Turkey Creek
description: rises in NW Bertie County and flows NW into Hertford County and into Ahoskie Creek.

label: Turkey Creek
description: is formed in NW Buncombe County by the junction of North and South Turkey Creeks and flows NE and N into Sandy Mush Creek on the Madison County line.

label: Turkey Creek
description: rises in W Duplin County and flows SW into Sampson County, where it enters Six Runs Creek. Appears as Turkey Branch on the Collet map, 1770. Called Turkey Swamp on the 1959 Duplin County soil survey map.

label: Turkey Creek
description: rises in SE Moore County and flows S into Little River.

label: Turkey Creek
description: rises in SW Nash County and flows S into Wilson County, where it joins Moccasin Creek in forming Contentnea Creek.

label: Turkey Creek
description: is formed on the Hertford-Northampton county line by the junction of Maple Fork Branch and a small unnamed stream that rises in Hertford County. It flows N along the county line into Kirbys Creek.

label: Turkey Creek
description: rises in S Onslow County and flows S into Spicers Bay.

label: Turkey Creek
description: rises in S Pender County and flows SW into Northeast Cape Fear River.

label: Turkey Creek
description: rises in W Swain County and flows NE into Nantahala River.

label: Turkey Creek
description: is formed in N Transylvania County by the junction of South Prong Turkey Creek and North Prong Turkey Creek and flows SW into Davidson River.

label: Turkey Knob
description: N Henderson County near the head of Laurel Branch. Alt. approx. 3,600.

label: Turkey Knob
description: on Slickens Creek in E Jackson County.

label: Turkey Knob
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line. Alt. 4,540.

label: Turkey Mountain
description: W Madison County between Baltimore Branch and Spring Creek.

label: Turkey Swamp
description: rises in S Martin County and flows S into Tranters Creek.

label: Turkeypen Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows S into Pile Creek.

label: Turner Creek
description: rises in S central Carteret County a short distance E of Beaufort and flows E approx. 1 mi. into Cheny Bay and North River.

label: Turner Crossroads
description: community in E Cleveland County. Alt. 985.

label: Turner Crossroads
description: community in N Northampton County N of Cypress Creek.

label: Turnpike Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows NW into Valley River.

label: Union
description: community in S Hertford County. Inc. 1889; charter repealed 1939. Brittle Ordinary appears at the location on the Collet map, 1770; in 1808 it was called Brickle Inn. A post office with the name Union operated, 1878-1906.

label: Union Cross
description: community in SE Forsyth County.

label: Union Grove
description: community in N Iredell County. Settled prior to 1847, when a Methodist church was built. Named for a grove of trees in which union camp meetings were held. Alt. 850.

label: Union Hill
description: community in W Surry County between Little Mountain and South Fork.

label: Union Ridge
description: community in N Alamance County. Named for an old church that stood on the ridge there between Tom's Creek and Jordan Creek.

label: Union Township
description: N Pender County.

label: Union Township
description: S central Randolph County.

label: Union Township
description: SW Robeson County.

label: Union Township
description: SW Rutherford County.

label: Upper Creek
description: rises in NW Burke County and flows S and SE to join Irish Creek in forming Warrior Fork [Catawba River].

label: Upper Creek
description: rises in S Transylvania County and flows SW into East Fork French Broad River.

label: Upper Falls
description: in Snowbird Creek in SW Graham County. Water pours over a steep rock for 75 to 100 ft.

label: Upper Falls
description: the first of a series of three waterfalls on Yellowstone Prong, S Haywood County.

label: Vale
description: community in central Avery County.

label: Valhalla
description: community in central Chowan County. Alt. 39.

label: Vance Mountain
description: SW Cherokee County between Hot House and Rapier Mill Creeks. Probably named for Governor Zebulon B. Vance (1830-94).

label: Venable
description: community in S Surry County served by post office, 1880-1905.

label: Vineyard Mountain
description: S Clay County. Alt. approx. 4,900. An Englishman is said to have covered the mountain with grapevines, but his vineyard failed to prosper and he returned to England.

label: Wagon Road Gap
description: on the Haywood-Transylvania county line at the NW tip of Wagon Road Ridge. Began as a foot trail for man and horse on way to Brevard; later was widened for 2-wheeled wagons to haul salt and other provisions and eventually to accommodate large, 4-wheeled wagons, hence the name. The Blue Ridge Parkway now crosses the Wagon Road there. Alt. 4,535.

label: Wagoner
description: community in E central Ashe County.

label: Walker Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows W to join Corner Rock Creek in forming Dillingham Creek. Walker Falls are on the stream.

label: Walker Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County near Brushy Knob and flows W through Walkertown into North Fork [Swannanoa River].

label: Walker Branch
description: rises in central Lincoln and flows SW into Clark Creek.

label: Walker Gap
description: in Yellow Creek Mountains in N Graham County.

label: Walker Knob
description: NE Buncombe County near Balsam Gap in the Great Craggy Mountains.

label: Walkers Creek
description: rises in N Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park on the S slope of Mount Davis and flows S on the E side of Locust Ridge into Hazel Creek.

label: Walkertown
description: community in NE Buncombe County.

label: Wallace Branch
description: rises in central Lee County and flows NE into Lick Creek.

label: Wallace Branch
description: rises in central Macon County and flows SE into Cartoogechaye Creek.

label: Wallace Creek
description: rises in NE Mecklenburg County and flows NE into Cabarrus County, where it enters Reedy Creek.

label: Wallace Gap
description: SW Macon County between the head of Allison Creek and Nantahala River.

label: Walnut Cove
description: W Macon County on a tributary of Nantahala River.

label: Walnut Cove Branch
description: rises in S Madison County and flows SE into Little Sandymush Creek.

label: Walnut Creek
description: rises in E Macon County and flows SW into Cullasaja River.

label: Walnut Creek
description: rises in central Madison County and flows SW into French Broad River.

label: Walnut Creek
description: rises in N Polk County and flows SE into Green River. See Bizzell Millpond.

label: Walnut Creek
description: rises in W Wake County on the E edge of the town of Cary; S of the city of Raleigh, it flows E into Neuse River. Appears as Wallnut-Tree Creek on the Collet map, 1770.

label: Walnut Gap
description: on the Macon-Jackson county line. Alt. 4,150.

label: Walnut Gap
description: N Madison County at the head of Walnut Creek.

label: Walnut Grove Township
description: W central Granville County.

label: Walnut Knob
description: on the Alexander-Wilkes county line. Alt. approx. 1,990.

label: Walnut Knob
description: central Madison County on the S end of Pilot Ridge.

label: Ward Creek
description: rises in E Carteret County and flows S into North River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733.

label: Ward Gap
description: on the Burke-Cleveland county line.

label: Wards Mountain
description: N Avery County.

label: Warrior Creek
description: rises in central Caldwell County and flows NE into Yadkin River in W end of Happy Valley.

label: Warrior Creek
description: rises in S Wilkes County and flows N into W. Kerr Scott Reservoir. Originally known as Bear Creek. Daniel Boone's wilderness trail into Kentucky passed nearby.

label: Warrior Mountain
description: S Polk County. See Big Warrior Mountain and Little Warrior Mountain.

label: Wash Creek
description: rises in central Henderson County and flows SE into Mud Creek.

label: Washington County
description: was formed in 1799 from Tyrrell County. Located in the E section of the state, it is bounded by Tyrrell, Hyde, Beaufort, Martin, and Bertie Counties and by Albemarle Sound. It was named for George Washington (1732-99). Area: 420 sq. mi. (336, land; 84, water). County seat: Plymouth, with an elevation of 21 ft. Townships are Lees Mills, Plymouth, Scuppernong, and Skinnersville. Produces tobacco, peanuts, corn, soybeans, wheat, Irish potatoes, wood products, seafood, hogs, livestock, lumber, and paper.

label: Washington Township
description: NW Beaufort County.

label: Watauga Falls
description: on Watauga River in W Watauga County near Laurel Creek Falls at mouth of Laurel Creek.

label: Water Fork
description: rises in W Orange County and flows S into Bear Creek.

label: Watery Branch
description: rises in W Johnston County and flows E into Juniper Swamp.

label: Watery Branch
description: rises in N Scotland County and flows NE into Lumber River.

label: Watery Branch
description: rises in NE Wayne County near the town of Eureka and flows NE into Greene County, where it enters Contentnea Creek.

label: Watson Gap
description: W Jackson County on Cox Branch.

label: Wayside
description: community in central Hoke County between Beaver Creek and Black Branch.

label: Weaver Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SW into Junaluska Creek.

label: Weaver Creek
description: rises in E Chatham County and flows NW into Beaver Creek.

label: Webb Branch
description: rises in SW Buncombe County near Holland Mountain and flows SW into Hominy Creek.

label: Webb Creek
description: rises in E central Avery County and flows SE into Gragg Prong.

label: Webb Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows SW into Gap Creek.

label: Webb Creek
description: is formed in NE Cherokee County by the junction of Left Fork Webb Creek and Right Fork Webb Creek and flows SE into Valley River.

label: Webbs
description: community in S Edgecombe County near headwaters of Otter Creek.

label: Webster Creek
description: a short tidal creek and inlet, rises on the W side of the mainland of S Currituck County and flows E into Currituck Sound.

label: Welch Branch
description: rises in N Swain County and flows SE into Bear Creek.

label: Welch Branch
description: rises in S Swain County and flows NW into Yalaka Creek.

label: Welcome
description: community in N Davidson County. Alt. 860. Formerly called Hinklesville for the Hinkle family residing there. Disagreement arose over selection of a name for the new railroad depot; ultimately, Welcome was selected, either because the decision makers were impressed by the "Welcome" sign over the door of the community store or because, during the dispute over the name, one man declared, "Everybody's welcome here."

label: Wells Creek
description: rises in S Alamance County and flows SW into Cane Creek.

label: Wells Creek
description: a channel between Currituck Banks and several small tidal-marsh islands in Currituck Sound, E Currituck County.

label: Wesley Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows SE into Bent Creek.

label: Wesser Creek
description: rises in N Macon County and flows NW into Swain County, where it enters Nantahala River. Named for a hunter who lived on its banks.

label: West Branch
description: rises in central Madison County and flows SE into Walnut Creek.

label: West Branch
description: rises in N Mecklenburg County and flows SE into Rocky River.

label: Westminster
description: community in W Guilford County served by post office, 1843-1904.

label: Westover
description: community in W central Wake County; formerly the site of Thompson, a railroad station. Settled 1917 and named for Westover, Md. Alt. 325.

label: Wheat Swamp
description: rises in N Lenoir County and flows NE on the Lenoir-Greene county line into Contentnea Creek. Named for John Wheat, who had an early grant of land there.

label: Whitaker Branch
description: rises in W Avery County and flows SE into North Toe River.

label: Whitaker Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows S into Town Branch.

label: Whitaker Creek
description: rises in E Cleveland County and flows S into Buffalo Creek.

label: White Branch
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows S into Junaluska Creek.

label: White Creek
description: rises in S central Avery County and flows SE into Linville River.

label: White Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County and flows NE into French Broad River.

label: White Lake
description: a natural lake in E central Bladen County. Covers 1,068 acres; max. depth 10½ ft. Appears as Granston Lake on the Collet map, 1770; later known as Bartrams Lake for William Bartram, who owned adjacent property and operated a gristmill near the lake. Apparently appears first as White Lake on the Shaffer township map of 1886; named for its white, sandy bottom and clear water. It first attracted outside interest about 1922 after roads made it accessible. Boating, fishing, and swimming. See also Carolina Bays.

label: White Marsh
description: stream in the lower course of Red Hill Swamp after it is joined by Western Prong, N Columbus County. It flows SE into Waccamaw River. Appears on the Moseley map, 1733, as Great White Marsh in the vicinity of Waccamaw River. See also Brown Meadow.

label: White Marsh
description: rises in S Pender County and flows W into Godfrey Creek.

label: White Oak
description: community in W central Gates County.

label: White Oak
description: former community in central Guilford County; now a part of Greensboro.

label: White Oak
description: community in SW Halifax County.

label: White Oak Creek
description: rises in SW Avery County and flows SE into North Toe River.

label: White Oak Swamp
description: rises in SE Bladen County and flows SE into Cape Fear River.

label: White Oak Swamp
description: rises in NE Edgecombe County near the town of Whitakers and flows SE into Swift Creek. Appears on the Collet map, 1770, as Peachtree Creek.

label: White Oak Swamp
description: rises in NE Franklin County and flows SE into Nash County, where it turns NE to flow into Fishing Creek.

label: White Oak Township
description: N Bladen County.

label: White Oak Township
description: W Carteret County on White Oak River and Bogue Sound. For a time called township no. 1.

label: White Oak Township
description: SE Jones County.

label: White Oak Township
description: NE Onslow County.

label: White Oak Township
description: central Polk County.

label: White Plains
description: community in SE Hertford County.

label: White Plains
description: community in N central Surry County. Alt. 1,150. Settled in the 1850s and named for the white, sandy loam soil in the vicinity. Eng and Chang Bunker (1811-74), famed Siamese twins, moved there in 1854 and are buried in a local churchyard.

label: White Rock
description: mountain on Haywood County, N.C.-Cocke County, Tenn., line near lat. 35°45'30" N., long. 83°10' W. Known in Tennessee as Sharp Top for its appearance from that state. A white appearance on the North Carolina side gives it its name. Alt. 5,025.

label: White Rock
description: peak in S Watauga County between Pigeonroost and Dutch Creeks.

label: White Rock
description: See Hill's Rock.

label: White Rock Branch
description: rises in SW Buncombe County near White Rock Mountain and flows NE into Warren Creek.

label: White Rock Ridge
description: E Mitchell County between Stagger Weed Creek and Sugartree Branch.

label: White Rocks
description: mountain on the Avery-Mitchell county line.

label: White Sulphur Springs
description: former popular resort in NE Surry County. Ceased operation about 1935.

label: Whitehurst Creek
description: rises in SE Beaufort County and flows E into South Creek.

label: Whiteoak Branch
description: rises in E Duplin County and flows S into Little Limestone Creek.

label: Whiteoak Branch
description: rises in NW Duplin County and flows S into Goshen Swamp.

label: Whiteoak Branch
description: rises in N Haywood County and flows NE into Pigeon River.

label: Whiteoak Branch
description: rises in S Johnston County and flows SE into Stone Creek.

label: Whiteoak Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SW into Tessentee Creek.

label: Whiteoak Branch
description: rises in E Montgomery County and flows E into Little River.

label: Whiteoak Creek
description: rises in central Avery County and flows S into Fall Branch.

label: Whiteoak Creek
description: rises in S tip of Burke County and flows NE into Jacob Fork.

label: Whiteoak Creek
description: rises in SW Wake County and flows SW into Chatham County, where it enters Buckhorn Creek.

label: Whiteoak Creek
description: rises in W Wake County and flows SW into Chatham County, where it enters New Hope River.

label: Whiteoak Creek
description: rises in S Madison County and flows SW into Ivy River.

label: Whiteoak Creek
description: rises in central Mitchell County and flows NW into Cane Creek.

label: Whiteoak Creek
description: is formed in E Moore County by the junction of Crains Creek and Dry Fork Branch, both of which rise in Lee County. Whiteoak Creek flows S into Crains Creek (the lower course of Dunhams Creek). It formerly was known as North Fork Crains Creek and Little Crains Creek.

label: Whiteoak Creek
description: rises in W Pender County and flows E into Moores Creek.

label: Whiteoak Creek
description: rises in central Polk County and flows E into Green River.

label: Whiteoak Creek
description: rises in N Rockingham County and flows NE into Virginia, where it enters Dan River.

label: Whiteoak Creek
description: rises in E Wake County and flows S into Johnston County, where it enters Swift Creek.

label: Whiteoak Flats
description: an area of stony loam in E Swain County N of Rocky Knob near the head of Adams Creek.

label: Whiteoak Mountain
description: N Haywood County, extends NE along the course of Whiteoak Branch.

label: Whiteoak Ridge
description: W Macon County parallel to Big Laurel Creek.

label: Whiteoak Swamp
description: rises in central Bertie County and flows S into Cashie River.

label: Whiteoak Swamp
description: rises in the town of Ahoskie, S Hertford County, and flows E into Bear Swamp.

label: Whiteoak Swamp
description: rises in W central Sampson County and flows SW into Great Coharie Creek.

label: Whiterock Ridge
description: N Jackson County near the headwaters of Buff Creek.

label: Whites Creek
description: rises in S central Bladen County and flows N into Hammonds Creek.

label: Whites Creek
description: rises in N Washington County in Chappel Swamp and flows NW and NE into Albemarle Sound.

label: Whiteside Cove
description: E Swain County between East Fork [Kirkland Creek] and Shepherd Creek.

label: Whiteside Mountain
description: on Clear Creek in N Henderson County.

label: Whitson Branch
description: rises in W Mitchell County and flows SW into Toe River.

label: Wild Branch
description: rises in central Madison County and flows ¾ mi. SE into Hunter Creek.

label: Wildcat Branch
description: rises in S Macon County and flows SE into Betty Creek.

label: Wildcat Branch
description: rises in S Swain County and flows S into Brush Creek.

label: Wildcat Branch
description: rises in SE Transylvania County and flows NW into Reasonover Creek.

label: Wildcat Creek
description: rises in N central Avery County and flows N into Elk River.

label: Wildcat Gap
description: N Graham County at the NE end of Hogback Mountain between Sawyer Creek and Stecoah Creek.

label: Wildcat Knob
description: N Buncombe County between Haw Knob and Carson Mountain.

label: Wildcat Knob
description: on Sassafras Ridge in S Graham County.

label: Wildcat Knob
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Wildcat Knob
description: central Macon County between Tarkiln Ridge and Trimont Ridge.

label: Wildcat Mountain
description: N Buncombe County N of Watershed Ridge between Sugar Creek and Paint Fork.

label: Wildcat Swamp
description: rises in central Bertie County and flows NW into Loosing Swamp.

label: Wildcat Swamp
description: rises in central Northampton County and flows SE into Potecasi Creek.

label: Williams
description: community in S Wayne County near Williams Millpond.

label: Williams Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County near Ingraham Mountain and flows SW into Dillingham Creek.

label: Williams Creek
description: rises in central Cleveland County and flows SW into First Broad River.

label: Williams Creek
description: rises in NE Montgomery County and flows SE into Moore County, where it enters Wolf Creek.

label: Williams Millpond
description: S Wayne County on a tributary of Northeast Cape Fear River. Dam and corn mill built there prior to 1915 by Robert Williams, for whom it is named. Max. depth 10 ft.; area 25 acres. Fishing and boating; open to the public. Owned by Elizabeth Wooten Holmes, granddaughter of builder.

label: Williams Mountain
description: E Haywood County, extends NE from Beaverdam Creek to Big Butte Mountain.

label: Williams Township
description: NE Chatham County.

label: Williamsburg
description: former town in NE Iredell County. Commissioners appointed and town laid out 1815. Long inactive in municipal affairs.

label: Williamson Creek
description: rises in N Rockingham County and flows NE into Dan River.

label: Willis Cove
description: E Haywood County. An unnamed stream that rises at Big Butte Mountain flows SE through the cove into North Hominy Creek.

label: Willis Creek
description: a tidal creek approx. 1 mi. long, flows E into Nelson Bay in E Carteret County.

label: Willow Branch
description: rises in E Bertie County and flows SE into Chowan River.

label: Willow Creek
description: rises on the Buncombe-Haywood county line and flows NE across Buncombe County into Sandy Mush Creek.

label: Wilson
description: community in central Buncombe County.

label: Wilson
description: city and county seat, central Wilson County. Alt. 147. An early community at the site that developed around Toisnot Baptist Church (est. 1803) was known as Hickory Grove. Tosnot Depot, est. on the railroad there about 1840, became the post office name. In 1849 Tosnot Depot and Hickory Grove were inc. as Wilson, named in honor of Capt. Louis D. Wilson (1789-1847), who died at Vera Cruz during the War with Mexico. Barton College is there. Long the site of large tobacco market. Produces textiles, apparel, concrete pipe, lumber products, processed meat, and grain. See also Hominy Heights.

label: Wilson Branch
description: rises in central Cherokee County and flows SE into Morgan Creek.

label: Wilson Creek
description: rises in E Avery County near Grandfather Mountain and flows SE into Caldwell County, where it enters Johns River at the Burke County line.

label: Wilson Creek
description: rises in central Craven County and flows S into Trent River.

label: Wilson Ridge
description: N Avery County.

label: Wilson Ridge
description: extends from SE Avery County into NW Caldwell County. Alt. varies from 2,500 to 2,696.

label: Wilton
description: community in SE Granville County at the head of Sand Creek. A post office operated there, 1826-1907.

label: Windmill Point
description: extends from W Carteret County into White Oak River. Named for the fact that a wind-powered gristmill was once operated there. Also known as Hatchell's Point for Armistead Hatchell, who settled there in the eighteenth century.

label: Windmill Point
description: point of land at the entrance to Silver Lake, Ocracoke Island in SE Hyde County.

label: Windmill Point
description: extends into Bay River in N Pamlico County.

label: Windy Gap
description: N Buncombe County between North Knob and Chestnut Knob.

label: Windy Gap
description: E Haywood County on the E end of Chestnut Mountain.

label: Windy Gap
description: W Jackson County on the head of Tatham Creek.

label: Windy Gap
description: at the head of Rocky Branch in central Macon County.

label: Windy Gap
description: on the Madison-Yancey county line in the Walnut Mountains.

label: Windy Gap
description: S Swain County S of Licklog Creek near Little Tennessee River.

label: Wolf Branch
description: rises in SE Alamance County and flows SW into Motes Creek.

label: Wolf Branch
description: rises in S central Alleghany County and flows E into Glade Creek.

label: Wolf Branch
description: rises in NE Buncombe County and flows W into Beetree Creek.

label: Wolf Branch
description: rises in S Cleveland County and flows NW into Long Branch.

label: Wolf Branch
description: rises in N Madison County and flows S into Big Laurel Creek.

label: Wolf Branch
description: rises in S Montgomery County and flows SE into Little Hamer Creek.

label: Wolf Creek
description: rises in S Buncombe County near Stradley Mountain and flows SE into Bent Creek.

label: Wolf Creek
description: rises in SE Cherokee County and flows SW into Fannin County, Ga., where it enters Ocoee River.

label: Wolf Creek
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows SW into Tuckasegee River.

label: Wolf Creek
description: rises in W Jackson County and flows NW into Cullowhee Creek.

label: Wolf Creek
description: rises in W Macon County and flows SE into Nantahala Lake.

label: Wolf Creek
description: rises in NE Montgomery County near the town of Star and flows E into N Moore County, where it enters Bear Creek.

label: Wolf Creek
description: rises in E Surry County and flows N into Chinquapin Creek.

label: Wolf Knob
description: central Buncombe County NE of Swan Mountain.

label: Wolf Knob
description: central Cherokee County near the head of Rose Creek.

label: Wolf Knob
description: on the Jackson-Macon county line.

label: Wolf Knob
description: on Jackson-Swain county line near the head of Yalaka Creek. Alt. approx. 4,900.

label: Wolf Mountain
description: extends NE in E Jackson County between Wolf Creek and Tanasee Creek.

label: Wolf Mountain
description: N Madison County between Lewis Branch and Wolf Branch.

label: Wolf Ridge
description: NW Cherokee County, extends NE between Gowans Cove and Hipps Ridge.

label: Wolf Ridge
description: N Clay County, extends NE from Tar Kiln Ridge to Trail Ridge.

label: Wolf Ridge
description: E Mitchell County between Charlies Ridge and Rube Green Top.

label: Wolf Ridge
description: N Mitchell County between the forks of Gouges Creek.

label: Wolf Ridge
description: NW Swain County in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, a spur extending SE from Parson Bald.

label: Wolfpen Gap
description: N Buncombe County between Ramsey Mountain and Bruce Knob.

label: Wolfpen Gap
description: N Jackson County between Black Mountain and West Fork [Moses Creek].

label: Wolfpen Gap
description: N Jackson County between East Fork [Dicks Creek] and Dills Creek.

label: Wolfpen Gap
description: central Macon County between Willis Cove and Trimont Ridge.

label: Wood
description: community in NE Franklin County served by post office, 1900-1957. Alt. 350. Settled about 1893 and known as Woods Store until 1913. Inc. as Wood in 1917; charter repealed 1961.

label: Wood Island
description: in the mouth of Cashie River in SE Bertie County. Approx. 2,000 ft. long and 200 ft. wide. See also Purchace Islands.

label: Woodburn
description: community in NE Brunswick County.

label: Woodlawn
description: community in NW McDowell County in Turkey Cove and on Limekiln Creek. Site of Cathey's Fort, a rendezvous point for the state militia led by Gen. Griffith Rutherford against the Cherokee Indians in 1776.

label: Woodside
description: community in S Pender County.

label: Woodville
description: town in NW Bertie County. Appears on the MacRae map, 1833, as Hotel, which was the post office name from 1840 through 1865. Inc. as Woodville 1911, taking the name of the Whitmell Hill Pugh home, which had been named for an estate in England. Adjacent to Lewiston, which see; Lewiston is the railroad name for Woodville. Post office operated as Woodville, 1912-65.

label: Woodville
description: community in NE Cherokee County in Nantahala National Forest.

label: Woody Branch
description: rises in N Cherokee County in the Snowbird Mountains and flows SW into Will Creek.

label: Woody Branch
description: rises in NW Haywood County at N end of Fork Mountain and flows 1½ mi. SE to join Conrad Creek in forming Little Cataloochee Creek.

label: Wootens Crossroads
description: community in N central Greene County. Named for the Wooten family, which ran a store there in the 1920s and 1930s.

label: Worley Cove
description: NW Buncombe County near the Madison County line.

label: Wright Cove
description: S Buncombe County SW of Ballard Gap.

label: Wright Creek
description: rises in E Beaufort County and flows N into Pungo River near Pamlico Beach.

label: Wright Creek
description: rises in NE Cherokee County and flows SE into Valley River.

label: Wrightsville
description: former community in NW Duplin County near the present site of Faison, which see. Appears on the MacRae map, 1833, but apparently declined after the est. of Faison.

label: Wrightsville Beach
description: island approx. 4 mi. long, E New Hanover County between Atlantic Ocean and Wrightsville Sound.

label: Yadkin Valley
description: community in NE Caldwell County served by post office, 1884-1953.

label: Yellow Creek
description: rises in N Graham County and flows W into Cheoah River.

label: Yellow Gap
description: SW Buncombe County between Green Top and Billy Cove Knob.

label: Yellow Gap
description: S central Burke County.

label: Yellow Mountain
description: W Avery County near the Tennessee state line. Alt. 5,269.

label: Yellow Mountain
description: NW Buncombe County SE of Davidson Gap.

label: Yellow Mountain
description: SE Clay County between the forks of Little Buck and Buck Creeks to Water Oak Gap. Alt. 5,000-5,050.

label: Yellow Patch Branch
description: rises in E Jackson County and flows SW into Wolf Creek.

label: Young Cove
description: SW Buncombe County E of Peggy Peak.

label: Young Mountain
description: W Cherokee County between Camp and Shoal Creeks.

label: Youngs Creek
description: rises in S Iredell County S of Troutman and flows SW into Rocky Creek. Now largely covered by Lake Norman.

label: Zillicoah
description: See French Broad River.

label: Zilphy Creek
description: rises in S central Stokes County and flows E into Dan River.

label: Zion
description: community in SW Lincoln County served by post office, 1900-1901.

label: Zion
description: community in SW Yadkin County served by post office, 1856-95.

label: Zionville
description: community in N Watauga County on Cove Creek. Alt. 3,159.

label: Zircon Mountain
description: S Henderson County near Freeman Creek.

label: Zirconia
description: community in S Henderson County. Alt. 2,084. Named for zircon mines operated there in the 1880s. Zircon discovered there in 1869.

label: Zoar
description: community in SE Union County near Lanes Creek. Served by post office, 1876-1900.

label: Zorah
description: community in NE Craven County served by post office, 1888-1904. Now known as Caton for David Caton, donor of land for local school.
